message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of scattered nodules and the family history suggest that the patient has neurofibromatosis type 1, which is an autosomal dominant disorder.

We refer to Google as a source for this question. The presence of scattered nodules in the skin is a characteristic feature of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). NF1 exhibits autosomal dominant inheritance, meaning that only one copy of the mutated gene is needed to develop the disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The family history suggests a genetic disorder, and the presence of scattered nodules indicates neurofibromatosis type 1, which is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Autosomal recessive inheritance requires two copies of a mutated gene, and X-linked inheritance involves genes located on the X chromosome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The family history suggests a genetic disorder, and the photographs show symptoms of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). NF1 is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The skin nodules suggest neurofibromatosis type 1, an autosomal dominant disorder. The family history does not provide enough information to determine if it is X-linked dominant or recessive, and the scoliosis is not a typical feature of X-linked disorders.

We refer to images and medical knowledge for help. The scattered nodules and physical findings suggest neurofibromatosis, an autosomal dominant genetic disorder. Blindness and cancer-causing high blood pressure are associated with neurofibromatosis type 2, another subtype of the disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical examination findings, along with the family history of a cancer causing extremely high blood pressure, suggest neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1), an autosomal dominant disorder. The scattered nodules seen on exam are café-au-lait spots, which are characteristic of NF-1.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s family history and physical exam findings suggest neurofibromatosis type 1, an autosomal dominant disorder. Scattered nodules in the skin are a common sign of the disorder, and scoliosis can also be a complication. Blindness and cancer-causing extremely high blood pressure are not specific features of neurofibromatosis type 1.

The presence of scattered nodules and the family history of cancer suggest Neurofibromatosis type 1, which is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Autosomal dominant means that only one copy of the mutated gene is needed to develop the disorder.
